newsitem.title: INDIA: India identifies states for oil palm cultivation.
newsitem.headline: India identifies states for oil palm cultivation.

text.p: India, which started oil palm plantings in 1991, has identified 11 states to boost domestic palm oil production, a nutrition official said on Tuesday.

"About 150,000 to 200,000 tonnes of palm oil would be available domestically by the year 2010," said Umesh Kapil of the department of nutrition at the government-run All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS).
The government has set a target to plant 80,000 hectares of oilseed palm by 1996/97 (Nov-Oct).
Kapil told a news conference that oilseed palm had been planted over a 20,000 hectares and another 800,000 hectares was expected to be covered over the next 10 years.
India aims for self-sufficiency in edible oils. But due to rising consumption the country has had to import in recent years to meet domestic demand.
It is likely to import 1.25 million tonnes of edible oil in 1995/96 (Nov-Oct), 75 percent of which will be Malaysian palm oil, trade officials said.

"There are a lot of Indian companies looking for joint ventures with Malaysian firms to produce palm oil," said Ashima Raheja, the Indian representative of the Malaysian Palm Oil Promotion Council (MPOPC).
Kapil said in India there was a wide variation in the intake of dietary fats between the rural and urban population.
He said a meeting was being organised in New Delhi later this month to review the nutritional aspects of dietary fats in relation to various diseases.
The event is being jointly organised by seven organisations including the Nutrition Society of India and the MPOPC.
